Title.evidence: Cost-Effectiveness of Fibrinogen Concentrate vs Cryoprecipitate in Cardiac Surgery: A Randomised Controlled Trial

Participants.evidence: Participants included 495 adult patients with acquired hypofibrinogenemia post-cardiac surgery.

Intervention.evidence: Patients were randomised (1:1) to receive either FC (4 g per dose) or cryoprecipitate (10 units per dose)

Objective.evidence: This study evaluates the cost-effectiveness of fibrinogen concentrate (FC) compared to cryoprecipitate in managing active bleeding in adult cardiac surgery patients.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the number of allogeneic blood products (ABPs) administered within 7 days.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was computer-generated, and allocation was concealed.

Number_Analysed.evidence: A total of 495 patients were analysed

Result_Outcome.evidence: Median 7-day ABP costs were CAD $2280 for FC and CAD $2770 for cryoprecipitate.

Harms.evidence: Adverse events were similar across groups.
